comments.text:
It's not so direct a thing.  Russia is already crossing all lines that SHOULD warrant stronger response from NATO countries than it is receiving.  They have been for well over a decade.  Russia having nukes should not paralyze it's declared opponents from acting appropriately in response to its provocations.  To let them do so is to take a gamble that they won't abuse said inaction, to continuously weaken Europe and NATO, in ways that will inevitably result in direct, potentially-nuclear, conflict, anyway(which, by all indications, is exactly what they will do in the future/what they are working towards, no matter what happens).  Yes, to respond now strongly is also a gamble.  When everything is a gamble, the potential success rate of their nuclear capabilities DOES matter.  It does figure into the equation since the threat is already there and imminent.  Gambling on possibilities is all we have.  Every action or inaction NATO can take, it's damned if you do, damned if you don't.  Long-term, short-term, this is all going to come home to roost.  Knowing, or even having an approximation of, just how faulty Russia's nuclear efficacy is **absolutely** important to the conversation.  Stop pretending it's not.



TL;DR Your mistake is believing that "not crossing lines" is without risk as concerns potential future nuclear war.  BOTH crossing lines and not crossing lines are risky in this regard.  The variables that feed into the level of risks, in either case, matter.  We are not in a situation of certainty in either case.  And whether Russia's nuclear arsenal is potentially effective or not certainly feed into that evaluation of risk.


Edit:  Adjusted for clarity.

comments.text:
Complex. 

Russia spends a lot of its GDP on weapons and they are perfectly capable of making shells, bullets and guns. They also can make tanks, artillery, drones etc. Most of their stuff is going to be fairly basic and they wont have anywhere near the tech advantage of NATO, but they can still make a lot of it. 

What they cant do is make enough artillery all at once to feed the needs of an active war which is why they were getting it from NK. 

Solders are another story. Russia is a large country and they are very good at conscripting and pressing men into involuntary service. Theoretically they have millions of men who they can force into the war. But Putin has been reluctant to force conscription and has been using other tactics. But the fact remains that he could force conscription and the only way to stop him would be a poplar uprising, which is unlikely for now.

I've been thinking recently about how that guy in *The Sun Also Rises* went bankrupt - "Two ways. Gradually, then suddenly."

I keep thinking about it with regards to the potential for the AI bubble to burst, but also about the Ukraine war.

We keep hearing that Russia loses troops at a much higher rate than the Ukrainians, but also Russia has been slowly gaining ground over the last couple of years. For a long time people have been saying that [Russia is due to run out of tanks some time soon](https://nationalinterest.org/blog/buzz/what-happened-to-all-of-russias-tanks-ps-100925) and I don't know if that will be the catalyst or whether it could be that they run out of artillery or if Ukraine's attacks agains oil refineries cause the front lines to be starved. It's not so direct a thing.  Russia is already crossing all lines that SHOULD warrant stronger response from NATO countries than it is receiving.  They have been for well over a decade.  Russia having nukes should not paralyze it's declared opponents from acting appropriately in response to its provocations.  To let them do so is to take a gamble that they won't abuse said inaction, to continuously weaken Europe and NATO, in ways that will inevitably result in direct, potentially-nuclear, conflict, anyway(which, by all indications, is exactly what they will do in the future/what they are working towards, no matter what happens).  Yes, to respond now strongly is also a gamble.  When everything is a gamble, the potential success rate of their nuclear capabilities DOES matter.  It does figure into the equation since the threat is already there and imminent.  Gambling on possibilities is all we have.  Every action or inaction NATO can take, it's damned if you do, damned if you don't.  Long-term, short-term, this is all going to come home to roost.  Knowing, or even having an approximation of, just how faulty Russia's nuclear efficacy is **absolutely** important to the conversation.  Stop pretending it's not.



TL;DR Your mistake is believing that "not crossing lines" is without risk as concerns potential future nuclear war.  BOTH crossing lines and not crossing lines are risky in this regard.  The variables that feed into the level of risks, in either case, matter.  We are not in a situation of certainty in either case.  And whether Russia's nuclear arsenal is potentially effective or not certainly feed into that evaluation of risk.

evidence.text:
It's not so direct a thing.  Russia is already crossing all lines that SHOULD warrant stronger response from NATO countries than it is receiving.  They have been for well over a decade.  Russia having nukes should not paralyze it's declared opponents from acting appropriately in response to its provocations.  To let them do so is to take a gamble that they won't abuse said inaction, to continuously weaken Europe and NATO, in ways that will inevitably result in direct, potentially-nuclear, conflict, anyway(which, by all indications, is exactly what they will do in the future/what they are working towards, no matter what happens).  Yes, to respond now strongly is also a gamble.  When everything is a gamble, the potential success rate of their nuclear capabilities DOES matter.  It does figure into the equation since the threat is already there and imminent.  Gambling on possibilities is all we have.  Every action or inaction NATO can take, it's damned if you do, damned if you don't.  Long-term, short-term, this is all going to come home to roost.  Knowing, or even having an approximation of, just how faulty Russia's nuclear efficacy is **absolutely** important to the conversation.  Stop pretending it's not.



TL;DR Your mistake is believing that "not crossing lines" is without risk as concerns potential future nuclear war.  BOTH crossing lines and not crossing lines are risky in this regard.  The variables that feed into the level of risks, in either case, matter.  We are not in a situation of certainty in either case.  And whether Russia's nuclear arsenal is potentially effective or not certainly feed into that evaluation of risk.
